holdings.text: The first paragraph of the notification grants exemption from sales tax on sale or purchase of textiles with effect from December 14, 1957, and appellants' textile goods fall within it.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chatterjee, learned counsel for the appellants, submitted that on plain reading of the notification the appellants were entitled to the benefit of the exemption if para I stood alone.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain reading of notification's first paragraph unambiguously exempts all textiles including appellants' stock; no dispute on this.

holdings.text: The proviso to the notification qualifies the exemption only in cases where additional duties of excise are leviable under clause 3(1) of the Additional Duties of Excise Bill, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: A plain and prima facie reading of the proviso without going into the distinction between goods class of goods would appear to show that an exception is made in cases where additional duties of excise are leviable by the Central Government under clause 3 of the Bill.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso carves exception restricting exemption where excise leviable and conditions (proof of payment) applicable; integral with conditions.

holdings.text: The proviso does not apply to goods not liable to additional duties of excise under clause 3(1) because they are not lying within precincts of factory, warehouse etc.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the respondent, however, repeated before us the argument which found favour with the learned Judges of the High Court based on the interpretation which he sought to place on the words any class of such goods in respect of which additional duties are leviable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Leviable' requires all conditions of clause 3(1) including situs; appellants' goods outside precincts, no liability.

holdings.text: 'Any class of such goods in respect of which additional duties of excise are leviable' refers to goods actually liable under entirety of clause 3(1), not merely class potentially liable.

anchor.surface_text: Now, under clause 3 1  of the Bill, learned counsel pointed out, additional duties of excise could be levied on cotton fabrics produced or manufactured in India and that it was only by reason of such goods not lying within the precincts of a factory, warehouse etc.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Class means goods satisfying production in India AND stocked in specified precincts; location essential for levy.

holdings.text: Supposed intention to avoid double taxation cannot override plain words of notification granting exemption.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt, statutes have to be construed as a whole so as to avoid any inconsistency or repugnancy among its several provisions, but if there is nothing to modify, nothing to alter, or nothing to qualify the language

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fiscal statutes construed by plain ordinary meaning; no equity or intendment; intent from express words only (citing Salomon).

holdings.text: Appellants entitled to exemption from sales tax on textile goods in stock on December 14, 1957 as proviso does not apply.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were therefore entitled to the relief from sales tax granted by the notification dated December 13, 1957.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Goods within plain exemption; no excise liability so proviso inapplicable; applies notification to facts.

holdings.text: Proviso and conditions form integral part; 'leviable' implies dealer can fulfill condition of proving payment of excise.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be disputed that the proviso and the conditions appended thereto form an integral part thereof. It is obvious that where the proviso operates it would be open to the dealer affected by it to pay the additional duty

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious reading: proviso enables exemption via proof where applicable; excludes where impossible.

holdings.text: There is no equity in a taxing statute; subject within or out on words alone.

anchor.surface_text: What we are concerned with is a fiscal provision and it has often been said that there is no equity in a taxing statute and either the subject is within it or not, on the words of the enactment or the rules validly made thereunder.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restates established principle for fiscal provisions.

anchor.surface_text: In this companynection we might refer to the observations of Lord Watson in Salomon v. Salomon Co. 1897 A.C. 22. 38. Intention of the legislature is a companymon but very slippery phrase, which, popularly understood may signify anything from intention embodied in positive enactment to speculative opinion as to what the legislature probably would have meant, although there has been an omission to enact it. In a Court

precedents.cited_proposition: Intention of the legislature is a common but very slippery phrase which may signify anything from intention embodied in positive enactment to speculative opinion as to what the legislature probably would have meant although there has been an omission to enact it. What the legislature intended can only be legitimately ascertained from that which it has chosen to enact either in express words or by reasonable and necessary intendment.
precedents.cited_holding: Intention of the legislature is a common but very slippery phrase, which, popularly understood may signify anything from intention embodied in positive enactment to speculative opinion as to what the legislature probably would have meant, although there has been an omission to enact it. In a Court of Law or Equity, what the legislature intended to be done or not to be done can only be legitimately ascertained from that which it has chosen to enact, either in express words or by reasonable and necessary intendment.
